0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Advanced cardiac life support: 300 mg IV/INTRAOSSEOUSLY by rapid infusion; a single-dose of 150 mg IV/INTRAOSSEOUSLY may be repeated
  • Supraventricular arrhythmia: Rate control: Initial, 300 mg IV over 1 hour, followed by 10 to 50 mg/hr IV over 24 hours; maintenance dose, 100 to 200 mg ORALLY daily
  • Supraventricular arrhythmia: Pharmacologic cardioversion, IV: 150 mg IV over 10 minutes, then 1 mg/min IV for 6 hours, then 0.5 mg/min IV for 18 hours or switch to oral therapy
  • Supraventricular arrhythmia: Pharmacologic cardioversion, oral: 600 to 800 mg/day ORALLY in divided doses to a total loading dose of 10 g, then 200 mg ORALLY daily
  • Supraventricular arrhythmia: Sinus rhythm maintenance in atrial fibrillation, IV: 150 mg IV over 10 minutes, then 1 mg/min IV for 6 hours, then 0.5 mg/min IV for 18 hours (or switch to oral therapy); after 24 hours, consider reducing infusion to 0.25 mg/min
  • Supraventricular arrhythmia: Sinus rhythm maintenance in atrial fibrillation, oral: 400 to 600 mg/day ORALLY in divided doses for 2 to 4 weeks, then 100 to 200 mg ORALLY daily
  • Ventricular arrhythmia, Life-threatening; Treatment and Prophylaxis: initial, 800 to 1600 mg ORALLY daily for 1 to 3 weeks (for total daily doses of 1000 mg or more or when gastrointestinal intolerance occurs, give in divided doses with meals), then titrate down to 600 to 800 mg ORALLY daily for one month
  • Ventricular arrhythmia, Life-threatening; Treatment and Prophylaxis: maintenance, 400 mg ORALLY daily, up to 600 mg ORALLY daily (given as a single dose or divided twice daily)
  • Ventricular arrhythmia, Life-threatening; Treatment and Prophylaxis: initial, 150 mg IV over 10 min, repeat for recurrence, follow with 1 mg/min IV infusion for 6 hours then 0.5 mg/min (MAX: 2.2 g/24 hr) per American Heart Association guidelines
  • Ventricular arrhythmia, Life-threatening; Treatment and Prophylaxis: initial, 15 mg/min IV for 10 min (150 mg), then 1 mg/min IV for 6 hr (360 mg), then 0.5 mg/min IV for 18 hr (540 mg) (manufacturer dosing)
  • Ventricular arrhythmia, Life-threatening; Treatment and Prophylaxis: maintenance, 0.5 mg/min IV after the first 24 hr (720 mg/24 hr) with a concentration of 1 to 6 mg/mL
  • Ventricular arrhythmia, Life-threatening; Treatment and Prophylaxis: breakthrough ventricular fibrillation/tachycardia, additional 150 mg IV over 10 min
  • Ventricular arrhythmia, Life-threatening; Treatment and Prophylaxis: IV to ORAL, less than 1 wk, IV therapy to initial ORAL 800 to 1600 mg/day; 1 to 3 wk, IV to ORAL 600 to 800 mg/day; longer than 3 wk, IV to ORAL 400 to mg/day

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• safety and efficacy have not been established in children
  • Advanced cardiac life support: pulseless ventricular tachycardia/fibrillation, 5 mg/kg by rapid IV bolus or INTRAOSSEOUS injection; may repeat up to 15 mg/kg; MAX single dose 300 mg
  • Supraventricular arrhythmia: IV: 5 mg/kg IV over 20 to 60 minutes (max dose, 300 mg); may repeat bolus of 5 mg/kg up to 2 times; followed by maintenance infusion of 5 to 15 mcg/kg/min IV (7 to 20 mg/kg/day); MAX effective doses up to 20 to 25 mcg/kg/min (29 to 36 mg/kg/day) have been used in infants; duration of maintenance infusion is usually 24 to 72 hours, followed by oral maintenance therapy if indicated
  • Supraventricular arrhythmia: Oral: 10 to 20 mg/kg/day ORALLY given once daily or in divided doses twice daily for 7 to 10 days, followed by 5 to 10 mg/kg/day ORALLY given once daily or in divided doses twice daily; higher maintenance doses (15 to 20 mg/kg/day) may be required in infants (younger than 1 year); when stable, maintenance dose may also be given on a 5 days per week schedule
  • Ventricular arrhythmia, Life-threatening; Treatment and Prophylaxis: perfusing tachycardias, 5 mg/kg IV or INTRAOSSEOUSLY over 20 to 60 minutes, may repeat; MAX: 15 mg/kg/day or 300 mg/dose

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Ventricular arrhythmia, Life-threatening; Treatment and Prophylaxis
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Advanced cardiac life support
  • Adverse reaction to drug - Ventricular arrhythmia
  • Angina
  • Atrial fibrillation; Prophylaxis - Operation on heart
  • Fetal tachycardia
  • Heart failure
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Myocarditis
  • Supraventricular arrhythmia
  • Tachyarrhythmia, Postoperative

mono.title: Black Box Warning
mono.mono:
Oral (Tablet)
Amiodarone has several potentially fatal toxicities, the most important of which is pulmonary toxicity (hypersensitivity pneumonitis or interstitial/alveolar pneumonitis). Liver injury is common, but is usually mild and evidenced only by abnormal liver enzymes. Overt liver disease can occur, however, and has been fatal in a few cases. Amiodarone can exacerbate the arrhythmia, e.g., by making the arrhythmia less well tolerated or more difficult to reverse. Patients with the indicated arrhythmias must be hospitalized while the loading dose is given, and a response generally requires at least one week, usually two or more.

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• Bradycardia episodes which cause syncope, unless used in conjunction with a pacemaker
  • Cardiogenic shock
  • Hypersensitivity to amiodarone or to any of its components, including iodine
  • Second or third degree atrioventricular block, if no pacemaker is present
  • Severe sinus bradycardia
  • Severe sinus node dysfunction

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Cardiovascular:
  • -- New onset or worsening arrhythmia may occur, with possible prolonged effects and fatal outcomes; monitoring recommended
  • -- Bradycardia has been reported
  • -- Preexisting implanted defibrillator or pacemaker may result in changes to electrical conduction properties (pacing or defibrillating thresholds) of heart; monitoring recommended with oral administration
  • -- Hypotension, including some refractory and fatal cases, has been reported, particularly with IV administration; monitoring recommended
  • Dermatologic:
  • -- Photosensitivity has been reported with oral administration and may be related to cumulative dose and duration of therapy
  • Endocrine and Metabolic:
  • -- Thyroid abnormalities, including hypothyroidism, hyperthyroidism (sometimes severe) and myxedema coma (sometimes fatal), thyroid nodules, and thyroid cancer, have been reported; increased risk for potentially fatal thyrotoxicosis and arrhythmia breakthrough or exacerbation; monitoring recommended and dosage adjustment or discontinuation may be necessary
  • -- Preexisting hypokalemia or hypomagnesemia may exaggerate degree of QT prolongation and increase potential for Torsade de Pointe; increased risk in patients with severe or prolonged diarrhea or those receiving diuretics and laxatives; correct prior to treatment when possible
  • Hepatic:
  • -- Elevation of liver enzymes has been reported; monitoring recommended
  • -- Hepatocellular necrosis leading to hepatic coma, acute renal failure, and death have occurred with IV administration at higher than recommended loading dose concentration and rate of infusion
  • -- Hepatic disease, including some fatal cases of hepatic failure, has been reported
  • Immunologic:
  • -- Anaphylactic/anaphylactoid reactions, including fatal cases, have been reported with IV administration, with an increased risk in patients with an allergy to corn or corn products (contains dextrose)
  • Neurologic:
  • -- Peripheral neuropathy has developed with oral administration and resolution may occur after discontinuation but may be slow and incomplete
  • Ophthalmic:
  • -- Optic neuritis and optic neuropathy, in some cases resulting in visual impairment that had led to blindness, have been reported; monitoring recommended
  • -- Corneal microdeposits have been reported with oral administration and may result in visual halos or blurred vision; monitoring recommended
  • -- Corneal refractive laser surgery is contraindicated by most manufacturers of corneal refractive laser surgery devices
  • Reproductive:
  • -- Pregnancy; may cause fetal harm, including cardiac, thyroid, neurodevelopmental, neurological, and growth effects
  • Respiratory:
  • -- Pulmonary toxicity, sometimes fatal, has been reported including hypersensitivity pneumonitis and interstitial or alveolar pneumonitis; monitoring recommended
  • -- Pulmonary infiltrates or fibrosis have been reported
  • -- Adult respiratory distress syndrome has been reported; monitoring recommended
  • Other:
  • -- Discontinuation of treatment or dose adjustment may cause unpredictable recurrence of previously controlled life-threatening arrhythmia; patient may require prolonged hospitalization during this time
  • -- Prior inadequate dietary iodine intake may increase incidence of amiodarone-induced hyperthyroidism
  • -- Surgery increases sensitivity to myocardial depressant and conduction effects of halogenated inhalational anesthetics; perioperative monitoring recommended
  • Concomitant use:
  • -- Avoid concomitant use with drugs that prolong the QT interval and drinking grapefruit juice

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• Amiodarone: AAP: Drugs for which the effect on nursing infants is unknown but may be of concern.
  • Amiodarone: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

mono.title: Adverse Effects
mono.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Bradyarrhythmia, Hypotension (Oral, less than 1%; IV, 15.6%)
  • Dermatologic:Photodermatitis (2% to 24%), Photosensitivity (3% to 10%)
  • Endocrine metabolic:Thyroid dysfunction
  • Gastrointestinal:Constipation (4% to 9%), Loss of appetite (4% to 9%), Nausea (10% to 33%), Vomiting (10% to 33%)
  • Hepatic:Increased liver enzymes (4% to 9%)
  • Neurologic:Abnormal gait (4% to 9%), Coordination problem (4% to 9%), Dizziness (4% to 9%), Involuntary movement (4% to 9%), Movement disorder (4% to 9%), Paresthesia (4% to 9%), Peripheral neuropathy
  • Ophthalmic:Corneal deposit, Microdeposits, Visual disturbance (4% to 9%)
  • Other:Malaise and fatigue (4% to 9%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Cardiac dysrhythmia, Congestive heart failure (1% to 3%), Prolonged QT interval, Vasculitis, Ventricular arrhythmia
  • Dermatologic:Stevens-Johnson syndrome, Toxic epidermal necrolysis
  • Endocrine metabolic:Hyperthyroidism (1% to 3%), Hypothyroidism (2% to 10%), Malignant tumor of thyroid gland, Thyrotoxicosis
  • Hematologic:Thrombocytopenia
  • Hepatic:Liver failure
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis, Hypersensitivity reaction, Lupus erythematosus
  • Musculoskeletal:Low back pain, acute, Rhabdomyolysis
  • Neurologic:Pseudotumor cerebri, Raised intracranial pressure
  • Ophthalmic:Blindness AND/OR vision impairment level, Optic neuritis, Toxic optic neuropathy
  • Renal:Renal impairment
  • Respiratory:Acute respiratory distress syndrome (2%), Pulmonary fibrosis, Pulmonary toxicity

mono.title: Mechanism Of Action
mono.mono: Amiodarone HCl is an antiarrhythmic drug with predominant class III effects of lengthening cardiac action potential and blocking myocardial potassium channels leading to slowed conduction and prolonged refractoriness. However, it also possesses electrophysiologic characteristics of all four Vaughan Williams classes. It rapidly blocks sodium channels like a class I drug, it applies antisympathetic action like a class II drug and has similar class IV negative inotropic effect in nodal tissue

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Oral: time to peak concentration, 3 to 7 hr
  • Bioavailability: approximately 50% (35% to 65%)
  • Effect of food: rate and extent of absorption are significantly enhanced; decreases Tmax by 37%, increases Cmax and AUC by 3.8 times (2.7 times to 44 times) and 2.3 times (1.7 times to 3.6 times), respectively

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono:
• Hepatic: extensive; P450 CYP3A4 and CYP2C8; N-deethylation
  • N-desethylamiodarone (DEA): active

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Bile: primary excretion site
  • Renal: negligible amount (less than 1%) as unchanged drug or DEA
  • Dialyzable: no

sub.title: Elimination Half Life
sub.mono:
• Amiodarone HCl: (IV, single-dose), 9 to 36 days
  • Amiodarone HCl: (oral, chronic dosing), 26 to 107 days
  • Amiodarone HCl, over 65 yr old: (IV), 20 days to 47 days
  • N-desethylamiodarone: (IV), 9 to 30 days (IV, single-dose)
  • N-desethylamiodarone: (oral), 61 days (oral, chronic dosing)
  • N-desethylamiodarone, severe left ventricular dysfunction: (IV), prolonged

mono.title: Administration
mono.mono:
• Intravenous
    • must be administered using a volumetric infusion pump preferably via a central venous catheter; use an in-line filter
    • (for conventional amiodarone injection) use PVC tubing, if infusion duration exceeds 2 hours dilute with D5W and administer in glass or polyolefin bottles
    • concentrations should preferably not exceed 2 mg/mL for infusions longer than 1 hour via peripheral vein; concentrations greater than 2 mg/mL should be administered via central line
  • Oral
    administer consistently with regard to meals

mono.title: Monitoring
mono.mono:
• efficacy: due to controversy and difficulty evaluating therapeutic response, have accessibility to complete range of procedures, including in-hospital and ambulatory continuous ECG monitoring and electrophysiologic techniques
  • liver enzymes; those on relatively high doses
  • thyroid function; at baseline and every 6 months thereafter or when clinically warranted, particularly in elderly patients or any patient history of thyroid nodules, goiter, or other thyroid dysfunction
  • closely during loading phase; when given for life-threatening ventricular arrhythmias, particularly until risk of recurrent ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation has abated
  • baseline chest X-ray and pulmonary function tests; reevaluate with history, physical exam, and chest x-ray every 3 to 6 months thereafter
  • ophthalmic examinations, including funduscopy and slit-lamp examination; at baseline and every 6 months thereafter
  • pacing and defibrillation thresholds; at initiation and during therapy, in patients with implanted defibrillators or pacemakers
  • perioperative patients who are undergoing general anesthesia
  • postoperative fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) and oxygen delivery to the tissues

mono.title: How Supplied
mono.mono:
• Generic
    • Intravenous Solution: 50 MG/ML
    • Oral Tablet: 100 MG, 200 MG, 400 MG
  • Cordarone
    Oral Tablet: 200 MG
  • NOVAPLUS AMIODARONE HYDROCHLORIDE
    Intravenous Solution: 50 MG/ML
  • Pacerone
    Oral Tablet: 100 MG, 200 MG, 400 MG

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
AMIODARONE
USES: Amiodarone is used for treatment of atrial and ventricular dysrhythmias. PHARMACOLOGY: Amiodarone HCl is an antiarrhythmic drug with predominant class III effects of lengthening cardiac action potential and blocking myocardial potassium channels leading to slowed conduction and prolonged refractoriness. However, it also possesses electrophysiologic characteristics of all four Vaughan Williams classes. It rapidly blocks sodium channels like a class I drug, it applies antisympathetic action like a class II drug and has similar class IV negative inotropic effect in nodal tissue. It also has antiadrenergic activity. TOXICOLOGY: Bradycardia may develop from beta adrenergic inhibition and prolongation of the refractory period. Prolongation of the action potential and refractory period can cause QTc prolongation. Toxicity in overdose is rare. The majority of toxic effects occurs during chronic use and include thyrotoxicosis, pulmonary fibrosis, and hepatitis. EPIDEMIOLOGY: Exposures are uncommon and serious toxicity from acute ingestion has not been reported. Adverse drug effects are rare but may be life-threatening. MILD TO MODERATE TOXICITY: Symptoms can include dizziness, nausea, vomiting, and bradycardia. Rapid IV infusion may cause hypotension. SEVERE TOXICITY: Bradycardia, heart block, and hypotension developed in a neonate after IV overdose. In theory, torsades de pointes could develop after a large overdose. ADVERSE EFFECTS: COMMON: Nausea, vomiting, malaise, fatigue, tremor, poor coordination and gait, and peripheral neuropathy, hypotension (with IV form). LESS FREQUENT: Constipation, anorexia, photosensitivity, dizziness, paresthesia, visual disturbances, elevated liver enzymes, pulmonary inflammation or fibrosis. RARE: Rash, toxic epidermal necrolysis, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, prolonged QT, torsades de pointes, dysrhythmias, hypothyroidism, hyperthyroidism, hyponatremia, headache, acute hepatitis, pancreatitis, noninfectious epididymitis, optic neuritis, optic neuropathy, blindness, corneal degeneration, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia, pancytopenia, aplastic anemia, hemolytic anemia, acute hepatitis, anaphylaxis, SIADH, myopathy, dyskinesia, myoclonic jerks, and extrapyramidal hypertony.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
AMIODARONE
  • Support: MANAGEMENT OF MILD TO MODERATE TOXICITY: Antiemetic medications and IV fluids can be used for gastrointestinal distress. Manage mild hypotension with IV fluids. MANAGEMENT OF SEVERE TOXICITY: Severe toxicity is not expected. If symptomatic bradycardia occurs, administer atropine; if unresponsive, use beta adrenergic agonists (eg, isoproterenol). Consider temporary pacemaker insertion. Treat severe hypotension with IV fluids, dopamine, or norepinephrine. Treat patients with torsades de pointes with IV magnesium sulfate; correct electrolyte abnormalities; overdrive pacing may be necessary.
  • Decontamination: PREHOSPITAL: Gastrointestinal decontamination is generally unnecessary. HOSPITAL: Consider activated charcoal in patients with large recent ingestions if the patient is alert and can protect the airway.
  • Airway management: Ensure adequate ventilation and perform endotracheal intubation early in patients with life-threatening cardiac dysrhythmias, pulmonary toxicity, or severe allergic reaction.
  • Antidote: None
  • Monitoring of patient: Serum amiodarone concentrations are not rapidly available or useful for guiding therapy, although they may confirm exposure. Monitor vital signs. Institute continuous cardiac monitoring and obtain an ECG. Monitor serum electrolytes, liver enzymes, and CBC after large overdose. Monitor arterial blood gases, pulse oximetry, and pulmonary function tests, and obtain a chest x-ray in any patient with respiratory symptoms.
  • Enhanced elimination procedure: There is no role for enhanced elimination.
  • Patient disposition: HOME CRITERIA: For small acute unintentional ingestions (a single extra dose, or less than a therapeutic dose for age and weight), if patients are asymptomatic, they can be followed at home. OBSERVATION CRITERIA: Any patient with deliberate ingestion, significant ingestion, or patients with comorbidities or symptoms, should be referred to a healthcare facility for observation. ADMISSION CRITERIA: Patients who remain persistently symptomatic despite supportive management should be admitted for further observation. CONSULT CRITERIA: Consult a poison center or medical toxicologist for assistance in managing patients with severe toxicity.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
AMIODARONE
TOXICITY: Maximal tolerated dose and minimal lethal human dose have not been delineated. ADULTS: Oral overdoses in the range of 2 to 8 grams have been well tolerated in adults, causing only slight bradycardia and QT prolongation. A man developed only prolonged QT interval after ingesting 11.4 g of amiodarone with phenobarbital. CHILDREN: A neonate with atrial flutter received 15 mg/kg IV over 30 minutes and developed 3:1 AV block, bradycardia, and hypotension, but recovered with supportive care. THERAPEUTIC DOSES: ADULTS: May be up to 2000 mg/day. CHILDREN: May be 2.5 to 36 mg/kg/day.

mono.title: Clinical Teaching
mono.mono:
• Warn patient to immediately report symptoms of pulmonary toxicity (hypersensitivity pneumonitis, interstitial pneumonitis) such as cough, wheezing, progressive dyspnea, or hemoptysis.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of new or worsening arrhythmias (ventricular tachycardia/fibrillation, bradycardia).
  • Advise patient to use sunscreen, protective clothing/hats, and to avoid tanning beds as drug causes phototoxicity.
  • Drug may cause constipation, loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, abnormal gait, poor coordination, involuntary movements, peripheral neuropathy, fatigue, or malaise.
  • Counsel patient to report signs/symptoms of corneal deposits, optic neuropathy/neuritis, or a change in visual acuity (blurred vision, decreased peripheral vision, visual halos).
  • Instruct patient to take drug consistently with regard to meals as food increases rate and extent of absorption.
  • Advise patient to avoid grapefruit or grapefruit juice with drug.
  • Notify patient there are multiple significant drug-drug interactions for this drug. Consult healthcare professional prior to new drug use (including over-the-counter and herbal drugs).
